answers.answerText: B. Relative decrease in retinal thickness OD

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/oncology3-4.webp)

The OCTs both demonstrate undulation of the RPE, as evidenced by the smooth “wave-like” appearance of the hyper-reflective layer (white arrows). This undulation is secondary to the drusenoid PEDs (blue arrows), in keeping with the past ocular history of dry-ARMD. The right eye OCT macula demonstrates reduced retinal thickness compared to the left eye, possibly due to past history of primary open angle glaucoma (yellow bracket). There is no evidence of subretinal fluid.

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/oncology3-7.webp)

The OCT macula demonstrates a large lesion causing anterior-posterior mechanical elevation of the overlying RPE and neurosensory retina. The retinal layers are largely intact overlying an area of hyper-reflectivity in the intra-retinal or sub-retinal space (blue arrow). This could represent a large pigment epithelial detachment. Additionally, there is a crescent of hyper-reflectivity under the RPE at the apex of the lesion (red arrow) and homogenous hypo-reflectivity underneath (white arrow). While the retina is displaced anteriorly, there is no evidence of vitreomacular traction.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on fundus photo, FAF, ultrasound and OCT of the lesion, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Keeping in mind the hemorrhagic component of the lesion, the location (mid to far periphery) on fundus examination, the large PED on OCT, and the homogenous component of the lesion with low internal reflectivity on ultrasound, peripheral exudative hemorrhagic chorioretinopathy (PEHCR) is the most likely diagnosis.

PEHCR is an uncommon degenerative process due to hemorrhage in the sub-retinal or choroidal region, often in the temporal quadrant. PEHCR is largely in older Caucasian females, with a mean age between 77 and 83. Hypertension and anti-coagulation therapy have both been demonstrated as risk factors for disease; however, very little is known about the pathogenesis of PEHCR relative to alternative choroidal masses. Clinical features include hemorrhagic or serous PEDs, sub- or intraretinal hemorrhage, lipid exudation and vitreous hemorrhage.

* PEHCR is an older population with female predominance, association with hypertension, no familial relationship, temporal to the macula, 1/3 bilateral with no choroidal excavation on ultrasound.
* Choroidal melanoma is a younger population with male predominance, no association with hypertension, familial relationship (BAP1 gene), macula location typically, 0.2% bilateral and choroidal excavation with acoustic hollowness on ultrasound​

**References:**

1. Mantel I, Uffer S, Zografos L. Peripheral exudative hemorrhagic chorioretinopathy: a clinical, angiographic, and histologic study. Am J Ophthalmol. 2009 Dec;148(6):932-8.
2. Shields CL, Salazar PF, Mashayekhi A, Shields JA. Peripheral exudative hemorrhagic chorioretinopathy simulating choroidal melanoma in 173 eyes. Ophthalmology 2009;116(3):529-35.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: Which of the following diseases have been postulated to be a variant or causative entity of PEHCR?

answers.explanation:
First proposed in 2012 by Mantel et al, PEHCR is thought to be a subset or variant of PCV. Goldman et al. in 2013 believed that peripheral polypoid lesions were associated with the large hemorrhagic PEDs seen with PCV. However, no clear pathophysiology has been unequivocally concluded at this time.​

**References:**

1. Goldman DR, Freund KB, McCannel CA, Sarraf D. Peripheral polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy as a cause of peripheral exudative hemorrhagic chorioretinopathy: a report of 10 eyes. Retina. 2013 Jan;33(1):48-55.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: What treatment is typically indicated for asymptomatic PEHCR?

answers.explanation:
Asymptomatic patients with PEHCR can be managed conservatively, as the Shields et al. study in 2009 demonstrated stabilization or regression in 89% of cases. However, if vitreous hemorrhage is present, pars plana vitrectomy would be indicated. Anti-VEGF injections and laser photocoagulation have been tried with variable success when intra- or sub-retinal fluid is present.

**References:**

1. Shields CL, Salazar PF, Mashayekhi A, Shields JA. Peripheral exudative hemorrhagic chorioretinopathy simulating choroidal melanoma in 173 eyes. Ophthalmology. 2009 Mar;116(3):529-35.
2. Pinarci EY, Kilic I, Bayar SA, Sizmaz S, Akkoyun I, Yilmaz G. Clinical characteristics of peripheral exudative hemorrhagic chorioretinopathy and its response to bevacizumab therapy. Eye (Lond). 2013 Jan;27(1):111-2.

title: Case 3
description: 88F presenting with decreased vision OD for 1 month
patientPresentation:
An 88-year-old female was referred to the ocular oncology service to “rule out neoplasm.” The patient symptomatically noted decreased vision in her right eye for 1 month. Her past ocular history included retinal detachment repair OD 15 years ago, primary open angle glaucoma controlled with topical agents, and dry age-related macular degeneration changes for the past 2 years. Vision was 20/50 OD and 20/25 OS with normal IOP and pupillary examination. Optos widefield fundus photos are shown below. Notably, a laser scar was appreciated in the far temporal periphery OD, along with a suspicious, well-demarcated, dark, circular lesion in the mid-far periphery at 10 o’clock.
